Akkadian

Akkadian is an extinct East Semitic language that was spoken in ancient Mesopotamia (modern-day Iraq and Syria) from the 3rd millennium BCE until its gradual replacement by Aramaic beginning in the 8th century BCE. It was named after the city of Akkad and served as the lingua franca of the Ancient Near East for many centuries. Akkadian was written using cuneiform script, adapted from the earlier Sumerian writing system.

Writing System

Akkadian was written using cuneiform script, which consists of wedge-shaped impressions made on clay tablets. The script is logographic-syllabic, meaning it uses both logograms (signs representing whole words) and syllabograms (signs representing syllables).

Cuneiform Signs

There are several hundred cuneiform signs used in Akkadian writing. Some common signs include:

Sign Transliteration Meaning
ğ’€€ a water
ğ’¹ diÅ¡ one
ğ’‚— en lord
ğ’ƒ» Å¡a of, which
ğ’…† mu name, year
ğ’†  ki place, earth
ğ’ˆ¨ me plural marker
ğ’‰º pa branch, leader
ğ’Š ra to go
ğ’Œ· uru city

Syllabic Values

Many signs have multiple possible readings. This polyvalence is a key feature of cuneiform writing. For example:

  • ğ’‰ can be read as bi, be, pÃ­, or pe
  • ğ’„­ can be read as á¸«u, á¸«um, or á¸«ub
  • ğ’€ can be read as ba, pa, or wa
  • ğ’€¸ can be read as aÅ¡, az, aá¹£, or in

The correct reading is determined by context and grammatical expectations.

Determinatives

Determinatives are unpronounced signs used to indicate the category of the following word. They help clarify the meaning in a script that often has multiple possible readings for each sign. Some common determinatives include:

  • ğ’€­ (DINGIR) before divine names Example: ğ’€­ğ’‚—ğ’†¤ dEN.ZU (the god Sin)

  • ğ’Œ· (URU) before city names Example: ğ’Œ·ğ’† ğ’…† URUki-mu (the city of Kimu)

  • ğ’Š© (MUNUS) before female names or professions Example: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ†ğ’‹«ğ’ˆ¨ğ’Œ MUNUSÅ¡ar-ra-tu-meÅ¡ (queens)

  • ğ’„‘ (GIÅ ) before wooden objects or trees Example: ğ’„‘ğ’ˆ  GIÅ ma (ship)

  • ğ’†  (KI) after geographical names Example: ğ’†³ğ’€¸ğ’‹©ğ’†  KUR aÅ¡-Å¡urKI (the land of Assyria)

Logograms

Logograms are signs that represent entire words. Many logograms were borrowed from Sumerian. For example:

  • ğ’ˆ— (LUGAL) = Å¡arrum "king"
  • ğ’‚Š (E2) = bÄ«tum "house"
  • ğ’· (KÃ™.BABBAR) = kaspum "silver"
  • ğ’ƒ» (Å A3) = libbum "heart"

Sample Text

Here's a more extended sample of Akkadian text in cuneiform with transliteration and translation:

ğ’¹ğ’„­ğ’„ ğ’ˆ¬ğ’Šğ’‰ ğ’ˆ— ğ’ƒ² ğ’ˆ— ğ’†—ğ’‰¡ ğ’ˆ— ğ’†³ğ’€¸ğ’‹©ğ’†  ğ’ˆ— ğ’† ğ’‚ğ’Š¹ğ’Š ğ’†  ğ’ˆ ğ’€€ğ’‹« ğ’€€ğ’Šğ’€ğ’€€ ğ’…‡ ğ’€ğ’…—ğ’²ğ’‚Š ğ’ˆ— ğ’† ğ’‰»ğ’‹« ğ’€€ğ’Š‘ğ’‰ğ’‚Šğ’‹¾ ğ’‰ºğ’‡» ğ’† ğ’‰ğ’Šğ’€€ğ’‹¾

1 á¸«a-am-mu-ra-bi LUGAL GAL LUGAL dan-num LUGAL KUR aÅ¡-Å¡ur-KI LUGAL kiÅ¡-Å¡at er-bÃ©-et-tim Å¡a-r ma-a-ta a-ra-bi-a Ã¹ ak-ka-di-i LUGAL kiÅ¡-Å¡a-at ni-Å¡i pa-li-iá¸« ki-ib-ra-a-tim

"Hammurabi, great king, mighty king, king of Assyria, king of the four quarters (of the world), king of the land of the Arabs and Akkadians, king of all peoples, reverent one of the (four) quarters"

This inscription showcases various features of Akkadian writing, including the use of logograms (e.g., LUGAL for "king"), determinatives (KUR for "land"), and syllabic spelling.

Phonology

Consonants

Akkadian had the following consonant phonemes:

Manner Labial Dental Alveolar Palatal Velar Uvular Glottal
Stop p b t d k g q Ê”
Fricative s z á¹£ Å¡ á¸« h
Nasal m n
Liquid l r
Glide w y

Notes on consonants:

  • The phoneme /á¹£/ was an emphatic consonant, likely realized as [sË¤].
  • The exact nature of /á¸«/ is debated, but it was likely a voiceless velar or uvular fricative.
  • The glottal stop /Ê”/ was not consistently represented in writing.

Vowels

Akkadian had four vowel qualities:

Front Back
i u
e a

Vowel length was phonemic, with each vowel having a short and long version. Long vowels are typically represented in transliteration with a macron (Ä, Ä“, Ä«, Å«).

Examples of minimal pairs:

  • Å¡arrum "king" vs. Å¡Ärum "wind"
  • ilu "god" vs. Ä«lu "they went up"

Phonological Processes

  1. Vowel Harmony: In Old Babylonian, the vowel of some prefixes and suffixes harmonized with the vowel of the root. This process affected mainly the prefix vowels of verbs. For example:

    • iprus "he decided" vs. ipqid "he appointed"
    • uparrĞ¸Ñ "he separated" vs. uparris "he separated"

  2. Assimilation: Consonants often assimilated to adjacent consonants. This process was particularly common with nasals and stops:

    • /nb/ â†’ [mb]: inbi â†’ imbi "he named"
    • /nt/ â†’ [nd]: imtaá¸«ar â†’ imdaá¸«ar "he received"
    • /np/ â†’ [mp]: inpur â†’ impur "he sent"

  3. Syncope: Short vowels in open syllables often dropped in certain environments:

    • kalabum â†’ kalbum "dog"
    • awilum â†’ awlum "man"

  4. Vowel Contraction: When two vowels came into contact due to morphological processes, they often contracted:

    • /a+u/ â†’ [Ã»]: Å¡a uldu â†’ Å¡Å«ldu "which he bore"
    • /i+a/ â†’ [Ãª]: Å¡i'Ämum â†’ Å¡Ãªmum "to buy"

  5. Consonant Weakening: Certain consonants, particularly /w/, /y/, and /Ê”/, often weakened or disappeared in certain positions:

    • awÄ«lum â†’ amÄ«lum "man" (in Assyrian)
    • ra'Ämum â†’ rÃ¢mum "to love"

  6. Stress: While not marked in writing, stress in Akkadian was likely penultimate in most cases, with some exceptions:

    • Å¡Ã¡r-rum "king"
    • i-pÃ¡r-ras "he decides"

These phonological processes played a crucial role in shaping the morphology and phonotactics of Akkadian, and understanding them is key to comprehending the language's historical development and dialectal variations.

Morphology

Akkadian is a highly inflected language with a rich system of affixes for nouns, adjectives, and verbs. Its morphological system is typical of Semitic languages, with roots consisting of (usually) three consonants that carry the basic semantic meaning, while vowel patterns and affixes provide grammatical information.

Nouns

Nouns in Akkadian are inflected for gender (masculine and feminine), number (singular, dual, and plural), and case (nominative, accusative, and genitive).

Gender

Most nouns have inherent gender, but some suffixes can change gender:

  • -um (masc.): Å¡arrum "king"
  • -tum (fem.): Å¡arratum "queen"
  • -Å«tum (abstract nouns, often feminine): Å¡arrÅ«tum "kingship"

Some nouns can be either masculine or feminine:

  • Å«mum "day" (usually masculine)
  • Å¡attum "year" (usually feminine)

Number

  • Singular: unmarked
  • Dual: -Än (oblique cases), -Ä (nominative) Example: Å¡Ä“pÄn "two feet" (oblique), Å¡Ä“pÄ "two feet" (nominative)
  • Plural:
    • Masculine: -Å« (nominative), -Ä« (oblique)
    • Feminine: -Ätum (nominative), -Ätim (oblique)

Some nouns have irregular plurals:

  • ilum "god" â†’ ilÅ« / ilÄ« "gods"
  • awÄ«lum "man" â†’ awÄ«lÅ« / awÄ«lÄ« "men"
  • Älum "city" â†’ ÄlÄnÅ« / ÄlÄnÄ« "cities"

Case

Akkadian has three cases:

  • Nominative: -um (sing.), -Å« (masc. pl.), -Ätum (fem. pl.)
  • Accusative: -am (sing.), -Ä« (masc. pl.), -Ätim (fem. pl.)
  • Genitive: -im (sing.), -Ä« (masc. pl.), -Ätim (fem. pl.)

Example declension of Å¡arrum "king":

Case Singular Plural
Nominative Å¡arr-um Å¡arr-Å«
Accusative Å¡arr-am Å¡arr-Ä«
Genitive Å¡arr-im Å¡arr-Ä«

Construct State

When a noun is followed by a genitive, it takes a special form called the construct state:

  • Masculine singular: -u (all cases)
  • Feminine singular: -at (all cases)
  • Masculine plural: -Å« (nom.), -Ä« (acc./gen.)
  • Feminine plural: -Ät (all cases)

Example:

  • bÄ«t Å¡arrim "the house of the king" (construct bÄ«t from bÄ«tum)
  • mÄrÄt Å¡arrim "the daughters of the king" (construct mÄrÄt from mÄrÄtum)

Adjectives

Adjectives agree with the nouns they modify in gender, number, and case. They generally follow the same declension patterns as nouns.

Example: dannum "strong" (masc. sing. nom.)

  • dannutum "strong" (fem. sing. nom.)
  • dannÅ«tum "strong" (masc. pl. nom.)
  • dannÄtum "strong" (fem. pl. nom.)

Comparative and superlative forms are usually expressed through syntax rather than morphology:

  • dannum eli aá¸«á¸«Ä«Å¡u "stronger than his brothers" (lit. "strong compared to his brothers")
  • dannum ina aá¸«á¸«Ä«Å¡u "strongest among his brothers" (lit. "strong among his brothers")

Possessive suffixes are attached directly to nouns:

Person Singular Plural
1st -Ä« -ni
2nd masc. -ka -kunu
2nd fem. -ki -kina
3rd masc. -Å¡u -Å¡unu

Example:

  • bÄ«tum "house"
  • bÄ«tÄ« "my house"
  • bÄ«tka "your (masc. sing.) house"
  • bÄ«tÅ¡unu "their (masc.) house"

Demonstrative Pronouns

Akkadian has several demonstrative pronouns:

  • annÃ»m (masc.), annÄ«tum (fem.) "this"
  • ullÃ»m (masc.), ullÄ«tum (fem.) "that"

These decline for case and number:

  • annÃ»m (nom.), anniam (acc.), annim (gen.)

Relative Pronoun

The relative pronoun in Akkadian is Å¡a, which is indeclinable:

  • awÄ«lum Å¡a illkam "the man who came"

Verbs

Akkadian verbs are highly complex, with inflections for person, gender, number, tense, mood, and voice. The basic verb stem consists of three consonants (the root), with various affixes added to create different forms.

Verb Stems

There are several verb stems in Akkadian, each with a different nuance:

  1. G-stem (basic stem): parÄsum "to decide"
  2. D-stem (intensive): purrusum "to separate"
  3. Å -stem (causative): Å¡uprusum "to make decide"
  4. N-stem (passive): naprusum "to be decided"
  5. t-stems (reflexive/reciprocal):
    • Gt-stem: pitrusum "to decide for oneself"
    • Dt-stem: putarrusum "to be separated"
    • Å t-stem: Å¡utaprusum "to make decide one another"

Conjugation

Verbs are conjugated for person, gender, and number using prefixes and suffixes. Here's the full G-stem preterite (past tense) conjugation for parÄsum "to decide":

Person Singular Plural
1st aprus niprus
2nd masc. taprus taprusÄ
2nd fem. taprusÄ« taprusÄ
3rd masc. iprus iprusÅ«
3rd fem. taprus iprusÄ

The present tense (also used for future) conjugation follows a different pattern:

Person Singular Plural
1st aparras niparras
2nd masc. taparras taparrasÄ
2nd fem. taparrasÄ« taparrasÄ
3rd masc. iparras iparrasÅ«
3rd fem. taparras iparrasÄ

Note the doubling of the second radical consonant in the present tense.

Tenses/Aspects

Akkadian has several tenses/aspects:

  1. Preterite (past perfective): iprus "he decided"
  2. Present (present-future): iparras "he decides/will decide"
  3. Perfect (past with present relevance): iptaras "he has decided"
  4. Stative (resultative): paris "he is/was in a state of having decided"

The stative is unique in that it uses suffixes rather than prefixes for person marking:

Person Singular Plural
1st pars-Äku pars-Änu
2nd masc. pars-Äta pars-Ätunu
2nd fem. pars-Äti pars-Ätina
3rd masc. paris pars-Å«
3rd fem. pars-at pars-Ä

Moods

  1. Indicative (unmarked)
  2. Imperative: purus "decide!"
  3. Precative (polite command): liprus "may he decide"
  4. Vetitive (negative command): ay iprus "let him not decide"
  5. Cohortative (1st person command): i niprus "let us decide"

The imperative has its own conjugation:

Person Singular Plural
2nd masc. purus purusÄ
2nd fem. purusÄ« purusÄ

Participles

Akkadian has active and passive participles:

  • Active: pÄrisum "deciding"
  • Passive: parsum "decided"

These decline like adjectives:

  • pÄrisum (masc. sing. nom.), pÄristum (fem. sing. nom.), pÄrisÅ«tum (masc. pl. nom.)

Infinitive

The infinitive is formed by adding -um to the verb stem:

  • parÄsum "to decide"

It can be declined like a noun:

  • ana parÄsim "in order to decide" (dative)
  • ina parÄsim "while deciding" (locative)

Verbal Adjective

The verbal adjective is similar to the passive participle but describes a state rather than an action:

  • parsum "decided, separate"

It declines like an adjective and can be used predicatively:

  • awÄ«lum parsum "a separated man"
  • awÄ«lum paris "the man is separated"

Numerals

Akkadian has a complex system of numerals, with different forms for cardinal and ordinal numbers, as well as special constructions for counted nouns.

Cardinal Numbers

1-10 in Akkadian:

  1. iÅ¡tÄ“n (m.), iÅ¡teat (f.)
  2. Å¡inÄ (m.), Å¡ittÄ (f.)
  3. Å¡alÄÅ¡
  4. erbe
  5. á¸«amiÅ¡
  6. Å¡ediÅ¡
  7. sebe
  8. samÄne
  9. tiÅ¡e
  10. eÅ¡er

Numbers 11-19 are formed by combining the unit with -Å¡eret "ten":

  • 11: iÅ¡tÄ“nÅ¡eret
  • 12: Å¡inÅ¡eret

Tens are formed with the suffix -Ä:

  • 20: eÅ¡rÄ
  • 30: Å¡alÄÅ¡Ä
  • 40: erbÄ

Hundreds use the word meat:

  • 100: meat
  • 200: Å¡inÄ meat

Ordinal Numbers

Ordinal numbers are formed with the pattern parus:

  • 1st: maá¸«rÃ»m
  • 2nd: Å¡anÃ»m
  • 3rd: Å¡alÅ¡um
  • 4th: rebÃ»m

Counted Nouns

When used with counted nouns, numbers behave in specific ways:

  • 1: uses normal adjective agreement
  • 2: uses a special construction: 2 + noun.dual Example: Å¡inÄ Å¡Ä“pÄn "two feet"
  • 3-10: noun in plural, number follows in construct state Example: Å¡arrÅ« Å¡alÄÅ¡at "three kings"
  • 11-19: noun in singular, number precedes
  • 20 and above: noun in singular, number follows Example: awÄ«lum eÅ¡rÄ "twenty men"

Syntax

Word Order

The basic word order in Akkadian is Subject-Object-Verb (SOV), but there is some flexibility due to the case system.

Example: Å¡arrum ÄlaÅ¡ ibni king-NOM city-ACC he-built "The king built the city"

However, other orders are possible for emphasis or in specific constructions:

  • OSV: ÄlaÅ¡ Å¡arrum ibni "It was the city that the king built"
  • SVO: Å¡arrum ibni ÄlaÅ¡ "The king built (it), the city"

Noun Phrases

Adjectives and genitives typically follow the noun they modify:

bÄ«tum rabÃ»m Å¡a Å¡arrim house-NOM large-NOM of king-GEN "The large house of the king"

Multiple adjectives can be used: bÄ«tum rabÃ»m dannum house-NOM large-NOM strong-NOM "The large, strong house"

Relative Clauses

Relative clauses are introduced by the relative pronoun Å¡a:

awÄ«lum Å¡a mÄram Ä«muru man-NOM who son-ACC saw "The man who saw the son"

The relative pronoun Å¡a is invariable and does not change for gender, number, or case. The verb in the relative clause agrees with its antecedent:

sinniÅ¡tum Å¡a mÄram tulid woman-NOM who son-ACC she-bore "The woman who bore a son"

Subordinate Clauses

Subordinate clauses often use the subjunctive mood and are introduced by conjunctions such as:

  • kÄ«ma "that, because"
  • inÅ«ma "when"
  • Å¡umma "if"

Example: Å¡umma awÄ«lum awÄ«lam iÅ¡Å¡iak if man-NOM man-ACC strikes "If a man strikes another man"

Temporal clauses often use the construct state of Å«m "day" with a verb in the subjunctive:

Å«m Älam Ä«rubÅ« day-CONST city-ACC they-entered-SUBJ "When they entered the city"

Coordinate Clauses

Coordinate clauses are often simply juxtaposed without a conjunction:

Å¡arrum Ä«liam ÄlaÅ¡ ibni king-NOM he-arose city-ACC he-built "The king arose and built the city"

The conjunction -ma can be used to connect clauses, often implying a sequence of events:

Å¡arrum Ä«liam-ma ÄlaÅ¡ ibni king-NOM he-arose-and city-ACC he-built "The king arose and then built the city"

Negation

Negation is typically expressed with the particle lÄ before the verb:

Å¡arrum ÄlaÅ¡ lÄ ibni king-NOM city-ACC not he-built "The king did not build the city"

In prohibitions, lÄ is used with the perfect: lÄ taptaras not you-have-decided "You must not decide"

Questions

Yes-no questions are often identical to statements, with only intonation differentiating them. The particle ul can be used for negative questions:

ul illiam not he-arose "Did he not arise?"

Wh-questions use interrogative words such as:

  • mannum "who"
  • mÄ«num "what"
  • ayyum "which"

These usually come at the beginning of the sentence:

mannum ÄlaÅ¡ ibni who city-ACC built "Who built the city?"

Infinitive Constructions

Infinitives can be used in various constructions, often with prepositions:

ana Älim erÄ“bim illiam to city-GEN enter-INF-GEN he-arose "He arose to enter the city"

Stative Constructions

The stative can be used to express resultative or stative meanings:

bÄbum petÄ« door-NOM open-STAT "The door is open"

It can also be used with adjectives: Å¡arrum dannat king-NOM strong-STAT.3SG.F "The king is strong"

This extensive overview of Akkadian syntax showcases the complexity and richness of the language's grammatical structures. Understanding these patterns is crucial for reading and interpreting Akkadian texts accurately.
